This is a print-in-place clip for sealing large bags like garbage bags, or any other large bag whose odor/humidity/dryness is best kept inside. The usual flat clips that bend around the bag may become difficult to use for large or thick bags, therefore this one is round and rigid, and relies on the flexibility of the bag itself. It can also be useful to hold cables or hoses together. Although the clip is easy to open and close, it can withstand quite a bit of force.
It comes in a 24 mm and 32 mm inner diameter (outer diameters are 33 and 42 mm). If you would like other diameters, just ask in the comments.

I know this thing somehow looks kinky, but using it for anything else than its intended purpose is entirely at your own risk ;)

The hinge and clip part were remixed from MasterFX' bag clip.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I printed this with only 2 shells which still produced a very strong result (in ABS). Use more shells or higher infill for extra strength.

Compared to MasterFX' original clip, I did reduce the tolerances of the hinge to make it less sloppy, so this may be a little more difficult to print.
Like the original, this should print fine without supports. You could enable them for a 100% perfect result, but I wouldn't know why you would bother making a garbage bag clip look perfect…
You may need to use a knife or screwdriver to pry the hinge loose if some strands of filament got inside it. Don't be afraid to use a bit of force, the hinge is quite sturdy.

A set of cable winders, inspired by spinning records, which are
both practical and novel. Works with all cables, from iPhones and
speakers to general power cables. Store your cables neatly and
always have them at the right length, of course with many audio
cables you should always fully unwind when in use to avoid
distortion. If the sizes provided don’t fit quite right then just scale
them to the custom size you need.

All parts are designed to be printed without support and snap
together so you can always reopen them to change the cable or
mix and match colors. Place your cable in the slot of the spool,
snap the casing around it and turn it from the grip in the back to
wind up the cable. To store it neatly you can pull the cable through
the slot in the spool to create a loop and push the ends though, as
shown in the photo. To unwind you can just pull either end of the
cable, which make the logo spin or record “play”.

title: Hex Base for Card-stock Miniatures
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I recently received a set of Pathfinder Monster Codex for Christmas, but I wanted more bases for a mass combat operation, so I made this design in Sketchup.

3 Versions Included

  • 2mm gap ~ Designed for Thick Cardstock e.g: Pathfinder Paper Miniatures approx. 2mm thick
  • 1mm gap ~ Designed for Single Layer “Cereal Box” Cardstock with two sheets of copy paper ( DESIGN A )
  • 1.5mm ~ Designed for Double Layer “Cereal Box” Cardstock with two sheets of copy paper ( DESIGN B )

Design A: cut a single piece of cardstock from a Cereal box and fold the paper miniature over it, then glue both sides down.

Design B: glue the full sheet of miniature print to the cardstock. Cut out. Fold and glue card stock to card stock, design B is thicker and yields a much more solid miniature.

Added Direction Indicator add on.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed a set ( one of each ) at high rez, took aprox 25 minutes.

description.text:
This a Clamp that I use to mount accessories to my RZR 900 roll Cage.

Clamp D has a recess in the back of the accessory mount to make it easier to swivel

You can build your own insert for the clamp to fit your specific needs or let me know and I will make the ones I have available.

The last 3 stl files are other variations of the same clamp with a different mounting configurations.

I usually chase the hinge holes with a 1/4" drill bit to clean up the holes

Carefully cut through the hinge joint with a razor to free them up.
Hardware:
2- 1/4" x 1" bolts
1- 1/4" x 1 3/4" bolt
2- 1/4" x 2" bolts
2- 1/4" flat washers
3- 1/4" nuts
2- 1/4" locking nuts
Either course or fine thread bolt are ok

comments.text: What kind of weight have you tested these with? I want to make some to hold up my sound bar and maybe some other stuff. Have you played around with any different materials at all?
comments.author: craigdieselmac

comments.text: I have used them on various things from light bars to rear windows and they are surprisingly strong. I have made them with ABS and PETG both seem to work well. As for a sound bar if you are worried about the strength look at the one that was remixed. It has been Beefed up quite a bit
comments.author: craigdieselmac

comments.text: Sorry the first clamp files that I put on where ones that I made for a guy that wanted to use metric bolts and nuts  on the accessory end so the nut traps and holes are a little smaller. I fixed that and all the holes and nut traps should be for SAE 1/4" bolts and nuts now.

title: Tiny Clean / Dirty Sign for Dishwasher

description.text: Inspired by rcaslis's excellent DishWasher dirty / clean sign, but I wanted something much smaller and compact. Other improvements include a snap-together design (glue is optional), and the cover surrounds the back and slider pieces, so multi-color printing layers do not show through on the sides in the final product.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

All pieces are in a single STL file. If you want to do multi-color prints, then you can split the grouping and delete components for individual pieces. At 0.2mm resolution, I paused at layers 0.8mm and 1.8 mm on the slider (for a white-green-white layering), and at 1.2mm on the back piece (for a white-red layering). I used the free online ColorPrint tool to add these color-change pauses: http://www.prusaprinters.org/color-print/

Glue and stick

Snap together and make sure all pieces slide that should, and don't that shouldn't. Trim / sand as needed. I added some glue for the final assembly, but make sure you don't add too much or it will squeeze inside and freeze your slider. I then cut a 3M adhesive sticker to size and stuck it to the dishwasher.

OpenSCAD

Want a different font? Perhaps a green check or thumbs up, and a red 'X' or thumbs down? Want it bigger or smaller? The design file is included with parametric variables for easy customizations.

title: Anet A8 modification for filament loader

description.text:
I did this modification because the changing of filament is a pain in the ...

If you don´t have any troubles, you don´t need this modi at all ;)

See it in action: https://youtu.be/wS0gAGX58vc

In this modi the cooling fan is a seperate block and can be opened for better view to the extruder while changing or to get easier access if anything is jammed.

The mechanism is not yet perfect... All the parts have tolerances that means you have to align your system once an than fix it.

UPDATE Cover design 20.01.2017
(New update! But for this you can still use the parts before update!)

I did this update for better cooling. For this solution the position of the heatsink is given but then you have to cut your heatsink after the fourth rib (see picture). The size of the heatsink is enough for cooling the buttom block. You can add thermal paste as well.

I did a 5 hours print -> the block was almost cold!

Fix the Motor and heatsink with two srews on the bottom left/right hole. Fix the cooler block assembly. It´s even possible to fix the block by 4 screws.
For the clamping screw I used a M3x25 a washer and two Nuts. Additionally you can use a spring of a standard biro.

That´s it, and if you want to cool the heatsink more efficient you can add two holes on the long top rib or turn the heatsink by 180 degree.

Thats for sure an option to handle the whole thing easier ;)
If you have any doubts, let me know.

Enjoy

Bill of material

2x M3x20 (heat sink)
3x M3x25
4x M3 Nuts
1x M3 self locking nut for the hinge (if available)
1x M3x40 (hinge)
2x M4x15 (20)
1x M3 washer
1x Spring of a ball pen

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

75

IMPORTANT NOTICE: There will be a while before i get another set of electronics so that i can do a "build with me" series for this one, sorry. So if you are not familiar with FPV, Quads and working with electronics maybe it´s best to wait. There´s also some programming needed of radio and flightcontroller.

If you still can´t wait i highly suggest you check out the resources about FPV below before even thinking about starting this project.

Joshua Bardwell on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/loraan
The Blue Falcon Project on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCObMtTKitupRxbYHLlwHE3w
Propwashed website: http://www.propwashed.com/

OpenRC 220 FPV Mini Quadcopter is the second quadcopter to join the OpenRC product family. It´s a modular, "self-supporting" design meaning that the design is as strongest when put together with all the other parts. This is a 220mm size using 5" props and the idea is to print all parts in a somewhat flexible material to allow for better impact resistance in a way that a material like Nylon for example will allow some "give" and thus better absorb a hard impact from a crash. The parts alone will feel "to flexible" but once they are in place and properly secured with screws it´s rigid enough. Even something like PCTPE may be suitable, haven´t tried it yet.

While testing i have found that a Co-Polyester like colorFabb HT based on Color Amphora HT5300 or Nylon filaments are the best suited for this design. A CF blend like colorFabb XT-CF20 och NylonX by Matterhackers will reduce the weight by approximately 20%.

As always questions are best asked in the community on either Google+ or Facebook

Below is a list of the printed parts needed:

6x - OpenRC_Mini_Quad_22mm_Spacer.stl
1x - OpenRC_Mini_Quad_Electronics_Frame.stl
1x - OpenRC_Mini_Quad_FPV_Ant_Lower.stl
1x - OpenRC_Mini_Quad_FPV_Ant_Upper.stl
1x - OpenRC_Mini_Quad_GoPro_Holder.stl
2x - OpenRC_Mini_Quad_Main_Body_Bottom.stl

description.text:
Just a quick thing I made with inspiration from Makers Muse. I feel like this could be some corporate trophy or something, lol.

It's designed to print well in spiral vase mode, which is a really fun thing to do because you can get fast prints that look good and use very small amounts of material. The only downside is that the print is very weak due to the thin walls. The example I have only used 22g of material!

Not much more to say about this one. Have fun printing!

Doesn't Matter

No

Doesn't matter

Notes:

Just use spiral vase mode (Slic3r recommend) and scale it to your heart's content!

Meshmixer stuff

I imported a plane object, generated a complex in order to increase poly-count, and then I decreased it a little bit and started moving around certain vertices by hand until it looked good. I really have no idea what I'm doing in regards to meshmixer, but I think it worked!

Hypercube Threaded Rod Support

This only works if your threaded rod reaches the top 2020 rail. You will need a 8mm bearing to press in.

Printed with my Hypercube: .1 layer height and 50% infill. Should be fine with .2 or better.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed in ABS. Parts are oriented to minimize supports, but they should still be used. Use a Brim for all parts.

description.text:
The Dremel Slicer tool will help you to make perfectly straight cuts in many materials with a rotary tool such as the Dremel 4000.

Print the parts provided, two of the base part. Note that there are two different sizes of the Base, print ONE of those two, twice. Dremel_Slicer_Base is shown in the pictures, Dremel_Slicer_Base_Short is the same thing but it holds the cutting board about 6mm lower. Again, print two of the same, not one of each.

In addition to the printed parts you will need two 8mm steel shafts, four LM8UU linear bearings, a 4mm x 35mm bolt and nut, a 3mm x 60mm steel shaft, and two small sheet metal or wood screws. You will also need a Dremel 4000 or similar rotary tool.

All of the above parts, except for the bearings, I salvaged from old equipment but they should be fairly easy to find online. The 8mm shafts came out of a couple of old inkjet printers, the 3mm shaft came from an old CD ROM drive they pretty much all have one. If you cannot find the 3mm shaft, a 3mm or 1/8 screw should work as well.

The length of the board will need to be at least as long as your 8mm shafts are. My board is 12mm or 1/2 inch thick. A 3/4 board will bring the work closer to the shaft of the Dremel if that is what you need. The short base will move the work further away from the Dremel shaft.

Jan 16 Update: I replaced the Carriage and the Hinge files. I reworked the hinge mechanism somewhat, I believe the Dremel will be sturdier than it was prior. It should also be a tad bit easier to print. Yes, I replaced the 123dx file as well. :)

A note on licensing. I appreciate credit and kudos for my work, everyone does. I do not disallow commercial use of my work. If you can make a buck or two off of this then good for you, go for it! But remember where it came from. If you find it useful then buy me a beer. If you use it to make money, then buy me a six-pack. Enjoy!

Printer:

DaVinci FrankenPrinter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

50%

Notes:

Printed in ABS. Parts are oriented to minimize supports, but they should still be used. Use a Brim for all parts.

Some assembly required, please use the pictures as a guide. The Dremel mount and Hinge pieces have holes for screws. Using screws will help to ensure that the mount is at the correct 90° angle. I used two small salvaged sheet metal screws and glued the pieces with acetone.

It will probably help to clean out the holes for the 8mm and 3mm shafts with a drill bit. (3mm = 1/8 inch)
Autodesk 123D design files are provided.

Tinkercad.com

This is a 26 mm watch strap based on the original one from the rather rare Abardeen F80 watch phone/smartwatch.

Not long after I designed and printed a replacement cradle for this watch phone, the original rubber band also began to disintegrate. The solution was obvious: print a new one! I copied the design so I could reuse the push pins, buckle, and tab from the original strap. Printing my own strap allowed me to create a shorter one that better matches my wrist, so it is a double win.

I used flexible PLA from rigid.ink. This needs to be printed on painter's tape because getting it off any other surface is an ordeal, especially BuildTak. However, as you can see from the photos, the texture of the blue 3M painter's tape causes a very nice ‘faux leather’ look, which makes this strap look a lot more stylish than the original!

Because it is so unlikely that anyone else will have the exact same strap with the same clip design, I also included the Blender file so it is easier to remix.

description.text:
Swedish style Mjolnir (Thors hammer) made simple so people without 3d modeling experience can make their own design in tinkercad

Gods with similar characteristics to Thor: Ukko/Perkunas/Perun/Perkele/Heracles/Hercules/Set/Ninurta/Indra

Will try to make the description, spelling, etc, as simple as possible:

Mjolnir (The crusher/pulverizer), representing the protection from Thor/Ukko but also you being the tool Thor uses to protect. Likley evolved from the axe of Perun, which evolved from a flint arrowhead. Possibly holder of lifeforce, the heart, ancestors cleansed spirits good karma.

Sun cross, representing the sun and the four seasons. Likely the origin of the Swedish Lucia (Lucia being the avatar of the sun with a sun cross on her head)

Troll cross, representing protection against trolls and the like.
(DISCLAIMER: likely not used until late medieval times, not actually viking age but has become popular within asatru)

Thurisaz/thorn rune ᚦ, representing Thor, might, bravery, devastation/destruction

Vegvisir (Way shower/guide), representing the holidays celebrated by Asatru
(DISCLAIMER: historical use is debated, no concrete evidence since medieval Iceland, however very popular now within asatru)

Aegishjalmur, (Helm of awe) to induce fear and to protect, made out of several Algiz ᛉ runes.
(DISCLAIMER: mention of the symbol is from the viking age, but the actual symbol is from the medieval period)

title: What is wrong with my printer?

description.text:
I have a Da Vinci 1.0A flashed with repetier using slic3r. It seems that the last few prints of mine have been doing this weird thing. I haven't been watching to see it happen, but when I look at the print, there is a clear line at exactly 40mm up where there is a slight layer shift. There is also a lot of stringing and general nasty print quality. This happens again at 80mm on the phone case.
Here are the example pictures. Notice that most of the boat is fine, but the smokestack starting at 40mm is messed up. The phone case attempt ultimately failed completely and turned to spaghetti. But you can see the lines I was talking about clearly. What is going wrong here?
One of them is this phone case, which prints on its end: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:469011
The other is 3D Benchy: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:763622

This is a very simple but effective mount for the mini height ir sensor which uses differential measuring to work with all sorts of heatbed surfaces.

The mount is meant to be super-glued below the j-frame of the Anet A8. The lower part of the pcb should be about 1.5 mm above the nozzel. The sensor itself can be attached with the two screws which come with the kit. I found that the 2.5 mm diameter holes are tight enough to fit with the delivered machine screws. You can fix them with nuts if you really want to.

There are two versions:

  • One is a solid mount with a height of 5.5 mm that may fit for stock Anet A8 setups. I also added the Fusion 360 project file for that which can easily be modified to different heights.
  • The second version is an adjustable version. I used that one to find the best height for my setup but then wanted to make the solid one.

if you are like me you have upgraded your off road lights to led light bars because of their compact design and unmatched lumens they can put out with little draw on your battery. but the one thing that i could never stand is the whistle or humming sound it makes when you're driving down the road. I've seen people shove things in the fins from cardboard to plastic wedges to stop this annoying sound. i wanted a cleaner look so i made this simple clip that wraps around the bar itself.

just simply print out a few of these depending on the length of your bar run a bead of black silicone on it and clip it on your bar and this will stop all the humming.

title: Carte de voeux - greeting card
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hello,

Bonne année à tous. Je vous souhaite santé, bonheur et succès pour réaliser tous vos projets pour cette année 2017.

Je vous propose une carte de vœux pop-up à monter soi-même, afin de souhaiter, vous aussi, vos vœux en 3D.

Plus de détail sur : www.buse-toi-meme.com

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Informations :

Temps d’impression 3D* : 1 heure et 5 min
Temps de réalisation : 30min
Niveau de difficulté : Débutant

*Les temps d'impression sont donnés à titre indicatif, ils dépendent du logiciel, paramètres et imprimante utilisés

Le Matériel :

0,80m de PLA
1 bâton de brochette en bois recoupé à 8,5 cm
1 papier carte format A6 imprimable
Colle à papier ou de la colle roller repositionnable

La Réalisation :

Préparation du Fichier :
1.Télécharger le fichier .stl sur votre ordinateur : busetoimeme-impression3d-cartevoeux.zip.
2.Ouvrir le fichier dans votre logiciel d’impression (Cura, CraftWare…).
3.Réglez les paramètres spécifiques suivants ou choisissez le mode qualité standard prédéfini par votre logiciel:
Vitesse d’impression : 50 mm/s
Type de support : Aucun
Type d’accroche sur le plateau : Aucun
4.Enregistrez votre Gcode
Préparation de la machine :
1.Insérez le filament PLA
2.Vérifiez les attributs de l’imprimante comme suit :
T° buse : 210°C
T° plateau : 60°C
3.Mettez une fine couche de colle sur le plateau (colle papier blanche en bâton - pas la peine d'avoir de la colle spéciale - Un plateau propre avec une fine couche de colle posée de façon uniforme permet d'avoir un meilleur état de surface au final.)
4.Chargez le fichier GCode dans l’imprimante et lancez l’impression.
5.Récupérez l’objet à la fin de l’impression en passant délicatement une lame de cutter entre le plateau et l'objet.

Mise en œuvre :

1.Imprimez le fichier " impression3d-cartevoeux-carte.pdf" sur la carte au format A6 :

  • la notice de montage au verso
  • Coté recto imprimez ou écrivez un texte selon vos envies
    2.Découpez les 2 fentes pour insérer le pic à brochette, puis collez l’impression 3D sur la carte.

l ne reste plus qu’à mettre sous enveloppe et à poster ….

Buses ;-)

Instructions:

Print the file using 1mm supports

Remove supports from the back of the trigger andthrough all the holes.
￼

Print using the proper settings for your printer and material.
Finishing may be accomplished by sanding, Acetone Vapor Bath, or whatever method is required for the material being used.

Use the drill from the helicoil installation kit to drill out all 3 holes in the trigger.

Use the tap from the kit to tap the center hole.

Install the trigger on your CS1/160R. Enjoy!

author: KevinKneppers

title: Sunhokey Prusa i3 Z end stop mount

description.text:
It's an end stop mount for the z axis. I finally got sick of the original and good enough at design to throw this together. The holes are designed to be screwed into, relieving the need for nuts. It fits firmly against the acrylic case and keeps the end stop pretty stable. All you could ever ask for in a 5 cent piece of plastic.

I designed it for the lowered height of the e3d V6 hot end. I had to add a nut to the head of the actuator to keep the spring tight, and it works well.
The actuator is an m5 x 25.

After printing, run some screws into the holes first to make threads.Mount the end stop, then mount it to the printer.

Now to set it up. Tighten down your bed springs. Level the bed based off the lowest spring height with an actual level tool. Then move the z axis to 0,0 and 0.1 above bed and measure with a gauge or paper. Move the hot end to 190,0 and twist the guide rods on the right hand side until the hot end comes down to 0.1 above the bed. This is going to make sure the carriage is level with the bed. If your bed springs are very tight I've found they won't tend to loosen up on you, and you get extra height out of the deal.

Get the mount in rough position so that it's activated in its current spot. Then home all axis, measure off 0,0 at 0.1 mm above the bed and fiddle with the set screw on the x axis until you get it where you want it.
Fusion 360

author: Phistterbut_Inc

title: Longboard Brake
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Longboard Brake – CruiseBrake

There are number of Longboards/Skateboard brakes with a deck attachment. E.g. Skate Safe V-brake (https://goo.gl/0CV83r) or Mingoskateboarding FrogStop (https://goo.gl/DfuLQZ). However, this kind of brakes reduces space under wheels and increases a possibility of wheel-bytes. Thera are number of brakes with a truck attachment. E.g. Brakeboard Trucks (https://goo.gl/eYoa3e) or SkateBrake (https://goo.gl/7az8ku). However, they are quite complex devices.

I have developed a simple truck attached longboard brake. It contains only wood, plywood and epoxy parts so it is easy to DIY.

The brake consists of a brake base with attachment wedges and a pedal with a rubber brake shoe. The brake base attaches to truck using steel ties. It connects to truck in two points for greater strength. The pedal moves and presses wheel due to the elasticity of the thin plywood pedal arm. How it works, you can see on the plans and photos.

Working title of the project is CruiseBrake.

The CruiseBrake has been developed for Caliber 50/180 trucks. However, it can be easily adapted to others truck models changing the Wedges parts shapes.

I recommend using 8-9mm Baltic birch plywood to make the Brake base part and 4mm plywood to make the Pedal arm. The Pedal pad and the Spacer parts can be made of any kind of wood or plywood. You should adjust the Spacer height to fit a wheel size. You also should adjust the Pedal pad height to fit you longboard deck thickness. The top of the pedal pad should be a few millimeters higher than the deck surface.

The pedal should be at the right side of the deck for regular foot riders, and it should be at the left side for goofy foot riders. You need to make different versions of Brake base for these stance styles. All other parts remain the same.

I know that many longboard riders refuse longboard-braking systems. However, some of them like ones. This design provides an inexpensive way to try, if a longboard brake system would be convenient to you.

Note: This kind of brake attachment is not very strong. I do not recommend this brake system for downhill and aggressive riding. It is intended to cruising. There is no any guarantee, use it on your own risk.

Please refer to http://www.townscooter.com/ for more information

author: gojoetofly

description.text: wolf cola, the right cola.. for closure...
Simple 1" replacement dowel rod wall mounts. 1/4" center through hole for mounting.
Yedt another way to hold the spool of filament. This is madde wqith 608 bearings and mounts on a 5/16" carriage bolt on the top.

• Print two of the spool hubs -- one for the bottom of the spool and one for the top. I printed with 50% infill and 1 extra shell. Note that this prints with the small end down to make the bearing hole clean.
  • put a 5/16" carriage bolt (about 4" long) througn the unused rod hole in the front of the top plate. Secure it with a nut.
  • Drop a 608 bearing onto the bolt and follow it with one of the spool hubs.
  • drop the filament spool on the bearing (note, filament spools are not symetric -- one side is almost flush, and the other side is inset to the hub. Put the flush side down.)
  • Add the second spool hub followed by the 608 bearing and a nut (I am using a wing nut).
  • It is important to "preload" the bearing so that it doesn't spin too freely. Screw down the top nut until it moves easily when pulled, but not witout a small pull.
I have a Canon SX50HS, it's a bridge type camera. I designed a box to store and transport my two extra batteries and two SD Cards.

I printed in the Felix 2.0 using slic3r with:
0.1 fill density,
0,2 Layer Height
2 perimeters

print_settings.Notes:: Please note (!): the STL files I've used fo printing were a bit different from hosted onese - just tried to remove some bugs with the original models, but even I've tested the files in 3dsmax, I can't guarantee there are no mistakes there. There must be none, but in case you find something, let me know, I'll fix it.

description.text:
Onece I thought: can I make a model using so simple reference as a few pixel graphics images? I've liked the game Dune 2 - The Building of a Dynasty made by Westwood Studios in it's time and always liked it's mentat/building menu units' images. I think they were a very good designed things. So I thought it would be a nice challenge to complete :)

It took a lot of time to make a model actually, since I didn't attend to it too much. I didn't like the way how the front and the back of the tank's body looked like, but overally the model looks nice anyway. I also thought maybe to make textures for the model and finally remake an original Dune 2 "slide", but got a bit lazy to do so.

But the case I was lazy was that I wanted actually to print this model and paint it. I don't have much experience in painting tanks, since I'm too far away from stand modeling, but, anyway, I just wanted to make a good try. You can see the actual photos of the result and decide it for yourself.

By the way, I've tried to find a lead Dune 2 designer - Aaron E Powell - to show the tank. It ought to be an interesting salute after 20 years, but, alas, didn't manage to find him - found three of his sites with (C)2014 stated there and with no reply for theese sites' local message system.

Hope people who still remember that nice old game will like the fact it is now possible to look it in real 3D and even being able to print it :)

Also there is an article (though in Russian) how I've made this tank. It includes more WIP images, just in case someone would be interested:
http://3dtoday.ru/blogs/harh/tank-of-dunes-or-sand-stone-axe/

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.125

Infill:

30

Notes:

Most was sliced using Slic3r and printed at 0.125 or 0.1 layer thickness with 0.4 mm nozzle with ABS plastic on a FlashForge Creator (not Pro version, just there is no standard Creator in the list). There was no raft, but I've used 5-7 mm brim. Model was done in 3dsmax.

Scale is 1.9% from the real size. Objects were scaled to that size before exporting. So if you want to scale it to the original values you know the scale.

There are two sets of files. First set is:

  1. SiegeTankBodyBR (BR stands for Bottom Ready; ready for printing - it is already netfabbed, so there are no holes etc)
  2. SiegeTankBodyTR (Top one)
  3. SiegeTankHookER
  4. SiegeTankTracksER
  5. SiegeTankTuskER
    This one is a complete set for printing the model. It doesn't need any support since all the supports are already included in the model. I've made theese supports just because Slic3r didn't want to make good printable supports for the model. The supports made are a bit more hard to remove since they are solid with the model, but I've decided it would be better to do it this way. Also, tracks model is made that way so it will not need any support and there are no supports in the model you would need to remove.

Second set is made in case you want to alter something. It is not completely ready for printing, but it is way easier to edit it:

  1. SiegeTankBody. This is a whole body that is not split into halves for printing purposes. Also, all theese models are not netfabbed. Model was done without open edges (all the elements are watertight), but there are polygons that uses the same space, intersections and things alike.
  2. SiegeTankHookE. This is exported version of the hook that doesn't have "integrated" supports and it also not netfabbed.
  3. SiegeTankTracksE. It is a way different model from the SiegeTankTracksER. Here is no model optimization for the printing. Form is original to the model I've initially made.
  4. SiegeTankTuskE. All the tusk without supports

Please note (!): the STL files I've used fo printing were a bit different from hosted onese - just tried to remove some bugs with the original models, but even I've tested the files in 3dsmax, I can't guarantee there are no mistakes there. There must be none, but in case you find something, let me know, I'll fix it.

description.text:
Servo linear actuator designed around a Emax ES08MAII. Should fit other micro 9g servo. Actuator length range from 95-137mm between M3 mount holes. The servo arm is 25mm and the linkage is 50mm. Subtract 92.03mm from actuator distance to trig servo angle and the equation below was written where servo angle 0° is straight down (retract) and 180° is straight up (extend) with angle limit 30°-150°.

The base frame and the retainer are to be glued together with the actuator rod assembled. I printed the rod Z up and it's weaker than I'd like so I would think about printing it flat on the bed next time. It's a rough design which I'll revise in the future.

Servo Angle = 180° - Degrees(ACos(((Act. Length - Act. Ext.)^2 + Servo Arm^2 - Servo Link^2) / (2 x (Act. Length - Act. Ext.) x Servo Arm)))

Servo Angle = 30° - 150°
Act. Length = Actuator Length 95 - 137mm
Act, Ext = Actuator Extension = 92.03mm
Servo Arm = 25mm
Servo Link = 50mm

Best Regards,
key ring key fob idea for my tattoo clients and friends

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Z-Axis Stop bracket

description.text:
I recently purchased a PrintInZ print bed for my Wanhao Duplicator i3. It's great, but it's thick, so you can't get the built in bed down low enough to get the PrintInZ bed in without adjusting the z-axis stop switch. There are two sets of mounting holes, and I found neither worked. There is a bracket that you can get from the Wanhao USA website, but I found that it didn't really work well. Once the screws were in place, they would slide up and down. There's a copy of it here on Thingiverse somewhere, but I can't find it right now to link to it.

Anyway, I made this bracket with distinct screw holes to give a tighter more stable hold.

You will need to take the screws out of the current z-axis stop switch to take it off. There will be two white circular spaces--save them, you'll need them.

Take one of the spacers and put it on one of the screws, then screw the z-axis stop to the bracket. Use a screw from another project to screw in the other side of the z-axis stop to the bracket. Then take the other spacer and put it on the other screw, and screw that in from outside the printer, through the pre-drilled and tapped hole, and then into the bracket. Add another screw going from the outside into the bracket, and you've got a secured switch.

You may be able to do it only with the screws that came with the printer, but I don't think it would hold up to repeated use, so I found some screws that worked in my screw collection. (What, we all have a screw collection, right?)

The pictures kind of show you how it works. They aren't the best, and I'm sorry.

Stewart Platform (6 Degrees of freedom) version 2 using (6) EMax Ex08MAII servo linear actuators. I used M3 screws and the servo linkage is formed from 1mmø paper clip wire. I have included my excel calculator along with the files for reference. It calculates the actuator length based on platform displacement in X,Y,Z, X:X, Y:Y, & Z:Z.

Servo Linear Actuator (95-137mm)
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2038205

UPDATE: 04-06-17
Added a few pictures/videos, 7" touch screen platform, X axis retainer.
Spending more time developing the PID control and tuning a bit allows the 6DOFv2 to balance a 0.75" bearing reasonably well. I still plan to fine tune even further. I did end up using an Adafruit STMPE610 (https://goo.gl/uHkAnf) touch screen control to get reliable location readings from the 7" touch screen (https://goo.gl/qONKCV); trying the (4) analog pin method resulted in too much noise and frustration. The (6) servo linear actuaors are driven by a (16) channel Keyestudio PWM driver (https://goo.gl/MrmK1g) connected to an Arduino Uno. While learning to tune a PID I stumbled across youtuber upgrdman (https://goo.gl/TWL8hO, https://goo.gl/hM7X9w) which developed his own telemetry software that reads arduino serial, very helpful!

UPDATE: 04-09-17
Arduino sketch and Fritzing schematic posted. I was able to achieve a stable balance that recovers from light disruptions while large disruptions propagate out of control. If anyone is able to contribute or refine it let me know.

Limits:
X +/-40mm
Y +/-40mm
Z +/-20mm (Z Home +128mm)
X:X +/-15°
Y:Y +/-15°
Z:Z +/-20°

Best Regards,

title: Dremel vise holder and PET Protection

description.text:
A vise holder for Dremel Multi (Mod. 395) with protection.

The nut and disc should be glued together, a transparent plastic is cut from a big PET bottle and glued into the groove around the disc.

The disc is actually two pieces, a outer ring and a center disc that are printed as one.
The outer ring can be rotate around the inner disc to put the protection plastic where it is needed without losing the nut.

The vise holder needs a M4 screw and nut to grip the Dremel.

title: Spur Gears and hole print test

description.text:

remixed_from.author: tomlombardi
remixed_from.title: Quick Change Build Platform for TOM

description.text:
Like many Thing-O-Matic owners, I ran into many problems with the automated build platform and eventually replaced it with the simple heated build platform.  I printed that way for most of a year, but I finally decided to revisit the ABP and see if its problems were fixable.  Thanks to many Thingiverse users' contributions, I have finally found a combination of fixes that works!
With the modifications described here, I now have the ability to quickly switch the ABP and HBP on my TOM, with no need to change any home offsets or Gcode.  The belt is now evenly tensioned, free of wrinkles and holds down to the build platform well. Also, since both platforms are removable, maintaining them is much easier.
Most of the design work here is due to others, but one key fix I discovered involves modifying the rollers.  Read on for the details.

Most of these upgrades are printable, so remember to print out all the parts in the list below before you disassemble your platform. 1) Replace the X-carriage with the Quick Change Build Platform for TOM by tomlombardi. The idler mod version is the best, and the small bearings can be found at hobby shops, as they're used in RC helicopters. 2) Build both a HBP and an ABP on top of tomlombardi's printed pieces. You'll need an extra heater board. You'll also need two aluminum counter-sunk build platforms (one for each). File the sharp edges off the aluminum for the ABP so the belt doesn't get worn out by the burrs. 3) Attach the ToM APB Belt Tensioner by gaerisl to the ABP. I found it helpful to file down the acrylic a little so the axle wouldn't catch as the system is tensioned. I didn't find bearings to be necessary. I also sanded down the part that contacts the X-min switch, to reduce interference and make sure I had as much X-travel as possible. 4) Make a Paper/Kapton ABP Conveyor Belt by AVataRR, about a quarter-inch longer than the stock belt. Mine is 290mm in circumference. I've tried plastic, steel, kevlar and I can say with confidence that the paper/kapton solution is the best. I use the cover of a stapled magazine for the paper because it's thin, strong and with the front and back covers being one piece, it's large enough to make a one-piece belt. It's also much easier with 120mm wide kapton tape. 5) Fix the rollers: this is my big value added. Sand off the tabs that slot into the rollers. Sand generously because the rollers are going to get larger. Cut some more of the tubing to fill in the gap in the rollers. Crown the rollers by wrapping 3/4" kapton tape around them at an angle. First layer should cover the central 2/3 of the roller, next layer should cover the central 1/3. Having the middle of the roller thicker helps center the belt automatically: http://woodgears.ca/bandsaw/crowned_pulleys.html. It also tensions the center properly, making up for the fact that the rollers bow in under load. Even tension is the secret to keeping the belt from wrinkling. 6) Assemble the belt onto the ABP and tension it up. Plug it into your machine so you can advance the belt. Run it forward for at least a minute at a time and inspect it. If wrinkles start to form, it usually means the tension is not equal across the span. Push on the belt where it comes off a roller to see where it is tighter and looser. Adjust the crowning of the roller and retest until tension is even and belt doesn't wrinkle. If the belt wanders to one side, tighten that side or loosen the other. 7) Attach an ABP wire clip by tomlombardi to control the wires. I use the screw that's closer to the bearing rods. 8) Put three thicknesses of kapton tape in a narrow landing strip along the -X side of the ABP, just outside of where the belt runs. This is where the nozzle will wipe the first extrusion. 9) Attach a TOM Z-min Endstop to your Z-stage. This allows much more accurate Z-height calibration that is independent of temperature/humidity, but also allows you to switch between the HBP and ABP without changing any offsets. 10) Get a Gen4 interface kit, or similar LCD command module. Install Jetty Accelerated Firmware. These go together like a hand in a glove and are by themselves more useful than everything else here. This will allow, among many other useful functions, to advance the belt as desired and to print several copies of an object consecutively. Acceleration is still somewhat beta, but you can always print in unaccelerated mode, which prints exactly like the old firmware. 11) Use the supplied start and end Gcodes in place of the defaults. The home offsets I use are X = -54.5, Y = -58.0, Z = -0.85. The dimensions are tight, so you may have to make small adjustments to start.gcode. The main thing is that the platform moves over far enough that the nozzle can drop below it on the side and allow the Z-min endstop to touch. Use the ABP driver in RepG, even when you switch to the HBP (it won't hurt anything). Enjoy your Thing-O-Matic repeatedly printing without human intervention, just like you always imagined!

title: Dual Bearing Spool Adapter Anet A8

description.text:
I originally printed the Parametric Universal Spool Holder and liked it but I wanted to make it better. What I did was:

  • Removed the smaller 1/3 of the cone as I had no spools that small.
  • Added a small ring to the existing bearing hole that would prevent pressure from being placed on the inner rasp of the bearing causing friction.
  • Added a second bearing to the small end of the adapter and included that ring to assist with less resistance on the bearing.

If you would like the clips and the washers from the original model, please print from the original link.

I did successfully print this and it works great! The bearings are a very tight fit but they do go in. I had to press them in with all my weight on a table top.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:767317

Thank you!

remixed_from.author: calviniba
remixed_from.title: Printrbot Play Wrap around 360 fan mount V2

description.text:
I've always had problems with cooling on the Play and decided that I wanted something that incorporates a hefty blower fan. Unhappy with the default shroud the Printrbot Play offered and inspired by calvinibas work I started working on my own shroud.

Note that this is a Work in Progress!

This design has several weaknesses:

  • The blower fan is only secured by one screw. I've secured mine with a bit of glue, but more support would be preferable.
  • It hard, but possible, to mount when the extruder is installed.
  • The blower fan is partly pointing at the nozzle, forcing the hotend to use more energy to keep the heat.

Printer:

Printrbot Play

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You need to flip the STL file upside down to print.

Installation

Installing this shroud is... finicky.

First off, you need to have the aluminium extruder that has three threaded holes on the bottom side.

To install this shroud, you'll have to take off the lower block of your extruder and take out your hotend.

Then, screw this mount to the extruder part. You need to use screws with small heads for this, otherwise you might run into problems mounting the blower fan.

Next, mount the blower fan to the one hole and tighten it up. I use a bit of loctite to get the fan to stick where it should be.

Reassemble the extruder now and screw in the small 30mm fan on the front.

description.text:
I am building a 3DR delta and I thought the push to fit approach could be better than the existing setup that calls for three screws and nuts.   
I did not pay much attention to the dimensions of Richrap's original part and mine came a bit oversized, but I hope it won't be a problem.  
Now there is a second version that should be pretty close to the right size.

You have to create a loop with the fishing line using the reel holes, and then wire a section of it clockwise and the other anti-clockwise on the available reel space.   
The motor needs to have a flat in the shaft.  
I printed mine at 0.2mm layer size.

comments.text: These do not fit NEMA-17 motor shafts.  If they're intended for a different motor than most people use, please post that information so people with NEMA-17's don't waste plastic printing these...

title: MP Select Mini Threaded Rod De-Wobbler Coupling
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a replacement coupling to connect the Z-Axis Stepper Motor to the Threaded Rod in the Monoprice Select Mini 3D printer. This is intended to replace the factory coupler, which has been reported to cause the rod to be misaligned and introduces wobble into the Z motion. This causes a banding effect in prints.

I have also included a Flex Coupler to try and address those of you who have alignment issues with the Threaded Rod and the Stepper Motor.

The complete detailed instructions for this modification are documented in my Hack-A-Day Project Log:

https://hackaday.io/project/14823-monoprice-select-mini-maximum-3d-printer-mods/log/51880-dont-go-wobbly-on-me-now

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.04375mm Layer Height is best to get the threads nicely defined.

Infill:

20% or more

Notes:

Use thick walls and thick top and bottom layers to make this a strong part.

comments.text: The stock coupling on my mini was pretty badly misaligned which caused quite a bit of z banding. This mod fixed the misalignment of the threaded rod and the z banding is fixed, but now the carriage does not move smoothly along the z and I'm having a heck of a time trying to get my first layer down since the nozzle doesn't always go to the same position (as it's moving along the z it will move, then stop for a split second then jerk quickly and repeat). I lubed the threaded rod with lithium grease and applied sewing machine oil to the solid rods, none of that seems to have helped though. Did anyone else run into this problem?
comments.author: lemonterror

comments.text: So I took my mini more apart and it turns out my gantry movement problem was due to a bad bearing. Replacement on the way but it definitely wasn't caused by adding this part, it's possible the bearing failed because of the original coupling, or the bad coupling was masking the bearing problem since it wiggled the bearing back and forth. I'll update after I install my new bearing, but this part definitely fixed my wobble issue.
comments.author: lemonterror

comments.text: Essentially the flex coupling is a helical coupler that a lot of printers and other CNC stuff use to help with alignment. Brilliant! :D

title: momo wheel paddle extender for Logitech g27

description.text:
-update 1/15/17 added STL. for paddles that work with higher offset steering wheels (steeringwheel sits further inwards).

  • This will work on a Logitech g27
    -STL. is for LH paddle to print RH simply mirror image in slicer
    -Printed out of PLA at 65mm/s 25% infill and a 1.2mm perimiter and top/bottom layer for strength.

-remove paddles from Logitech g27
-remember to remove the sticky rubber silencers on the back of the metal paddles we will use these later.
-take the original paddle bolts and thread them into the holes on the adaptor first to start threads, then pushed the paddle against the piece while screwing in the bolt till it bottoms.
-place the rubber silencers as seen in pictures on the backside of the extension just behind the two holes that go into the paddle slot on the g27.
-Fit the extension carefully into the paddle slot on the g27 and use x2 m3x15mm tapered head wood screws to hold in place.

  • the paddle is fairly close to the wheel i'm currently using as it has a shallow offset so I may make a new version in the near future, though if someone has a more of a "dished" momo this would be a perfect extension.
    -I also have a g27 to momo steering wheel hub adaptor posted as well, both mods work well together.

Like! Share! Give a shout out! Lemme know how it works!

description.text:
I have seen other mug handles online but they were not sturdy enough. This handle is stronger since the handle and ring are printed in one piece. I used 40% infill and three shells. I am also working on another design to make the handle thicker and longer for bigger hands.

I added a bigger handle design for folks with bigger hands. Hope you like it.

I added a flat handle design That I have not printed yet.

This is a simple print that makes cube of different sizes. Not only can this be a test print to make sure that it's making everything to the right size, but you can use it later on for reference of thinnesses and the quality of your printer at different sizes.
The size of the cubes go up by 1mm, starting at 1x1x1mm up to 6x6x6mm. It's a handy thing to have if you don't have a caliper around.

This is a holder for the VIKI LCD by Panucatt devices.  It mounts to the front of a kossel with the upper 15mm rail being captured by the hook on the back of VIKI holder.  Supports for the hook are incorporated into the model and need to be cut out.

Print on whatever resolution you're comfortable.  I printed with 100% infill and the first print curled in PLA.  I cleaned the print surface with alcohol and printed again with no curling.  This part needs to be strong as you'll be using it every time you touch your VIKI.  The space behind the LCD can be suffed with the cables to connect your viki, but also helps keep things cool.  The bottom three holes are for an M3 screw that fits into the bottom openbeam of the kossel base.  See photos if you're having trouble visualizing.    Enjoy

print_settings.Notes:: NinjaFlex Neon

description.text:
Upon inspecting my '06 Toyota Sequoia's engine bay I noticed a hose came loose from its bracket. The bracket was originally spot welded to a metal tube that connected the intake to the vacuum assist for the brakes. It probably would have been fine bouncing around for a while but it was engineered secured for a reason. My first thought was to get on the web and look for a replacement. Then I thought, maybe this would be a great job for some left over Ninjaflex.

I fired up TinkerCad and did the final touches in Sketchup to produce a quick and dirty bracket adapter. It may look a little crude but it sure does the job! It locks nicely in place and the hose has a nice flexible mount point.

NOTE: You MUST use a flexible filament as this bracket adapter is meant to stretch slightly over the existing bracket post and lock in place as well as stretch for the the hose insertion. Also when slicing the gap will appear for the hose insertion (tested with Cura and Slic3r).
To relieve tension of the hose simply bend the bracket to the rear slightly.

P.S. The original part to replace it was around $30:
http://parts.lakelandtoyota.com/p/TOYOTA__SEQUOIA/TUBE--HOSE-TO-HOSE--NO1/3976783/447630C011.html
Part# 44763A

title: QIDI Tech I dual extruder leveling Jig
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This jig will allow you to align the dual extruders on a qidi Tech I.

I made a few changes after the initial print which I used which have not been tested (cut sides to clear interference on fan bracket, .5mm enlarged opening for threads on screws)

tools needed to level extruders:
2x included Allen wrenches
3 small zip ties
flat bar for alligning the two extruders to be parallel

steps I followed (going on memory, leave a comment if I missed something):

  • print jig :)
  • remove and disconnect power
  • let cool
  • remove top acrylic shield if you have it in place
  • place a small zip tie around the left extruder stepper motor wiring so later on you know which one is the left
  • place a small zip tie around the left fan motor wiring so later on you know which one is the left
  • cut the zip tie holding the center wire bundle in place
  • if you have the side mounted fan:
    --- disconnect the fan motor plug from the harness
    --- remove the small screw that holds the lower part of the fan (nozzle)
    --- remove the two screws holding the side mounted fan in place
    --- remove fan and nozzle
  • remove the tubing from both extruders and cut the filament near the top of the extruder the filament holds the extruder in place after you remove the fans later on
  • remove the two screws facing up that hold the extruder assembly in place
  • extruder assembly should lift up
  • using the same screws that were holding the extruder assembly in place attach the leveling jig to protect the ends of the extruder
  • disconnect the cable from both extruders
  • remove the two screws at the bottom of the fan and head sink - note that each screw has a spacer - don't drop it into the bottom of the printer. set the fan screws, spacers, heat sink, fan shield to the side
  • remove the two screws at the top which hold the black plastic piece in place, remove the black plastic piece at the top
  • by pressing the filament release you can now remove the extruder motors and set them to the side
  • on the back of the aluminum bar there is a small set screw holding the hot end in place, loses both sides (don't remove
  • push the hot ends to the face of the jig, put the straight edge against the side of the extruders to line them up, and tighten the set screws.
  • re-assemble :)

Printer:

Qidi Tech I

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I used a higher infill, though I'm not sure it is needed. make sure to level the plate and use the extruder closest to the plate to print the jig.

remixed_from.author: iamjonlawrence
remixed_from.title: Timing Belt Y MXL, Printrbot Simple V2

title: Double Precision MXL Y, Printrbot SImple V2

description.text: This is for the Simple V2 w/o String tension. AFTER 10/23/2013 Printrbot added the string tension device and the mounting locations changed and will not line up with this design. If you want high quality parts than this is your ticket. This produces super smooth parts. The maximum speed is limited to about 50mm/sec due to a limitation of the number of steps/sec. the printrboard can output. Not too bad really since the posted limits of the Simple are 60-65. On the up side you can more than double your acceleration and XY Jerk settings, so overall print time is about equal if not better plus smoother prints! 2013/12-24, REV A: Update belt part number to longer belt. This one part number will give you enough length for both X and Y upgrades.

• The calibration values should be around 210 steps / mm.
  • A tip to get the belt length correct: Only secure the bearing holder for the 624 bearing temporarily at first, string up your belt, mark where it passes thru the belt tension block, then remove the 624 bearing holder to give you extra length to fold the belt back over itself.

comments.text: Will you do this upgrade for the GT2 pulleys, or would you have to switch if you want to upgrade to the double precision?
comments.author: sonicboom

comments.text: I have not planned on doing this for the GT2.  This thing was developed while I was troubleshooting my own quality issues.  It turned out to be a workaround, the real issue was in my motors. I have since moved to the standard GT2 drive with good results.  The GT2 belt form is simply a better choice for this application as it gives a smoother print due to the rounded tooth geometry.
comments.author: sonicboom

comments.text: If you can get the same quality with more speed, then perhaps this thing should be deprecated.
comments.author: iamjonlawrence

comments.text: To be completely honest, I haven't re-run the sample parts after I changed over to the GT2 belts.

author: Otacsum

description.text:
Remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1549787 for my 1982 Ford Bronco Schaper Stomper.

Can be remixed a variety of ways for other stompers.

The vehicle plate was scaled down to fit the wheel base of the stomper.

The name plate and base was scaled to 45%

The original vehicle base was scaled to 24.9% and then sliced to the correct wheel base. I took the base mount from a 45% version and moved it to the 24.9% so it will fit correct on the 45% scaled base.

-Enjoy

This is step 4 of my dream of having a Hex with a gimbal action camera. I'm using 1/2" wood square dowels for arms. I'm still missing lots of parts to get it in the air, but starting with the frame to see how much it may weigh and to come up with some sort of idea what motor/prop combo will be appropriate. I have printed the hub and am completely unsure if it will fly, if it is strong enough or even if it a good idea.

And yes, I know the SCAD file is a mess and is difficult to read and or understand. It's all my fault.

So caution, your mileage may vary. This might not even work. I highly suggest you to stop and go buy a Phantom or a Inspire or a S1000...
Greatest English Poet/ Painter.

author: nuggyblake

description.text: William Blake - Plate litho/ mural
I have moddified the "nerftracks" to work with my RC car TORMENT.

print 2 track bodys A and 2 track bodys B
print 2 drive wheels mod. these are the big wheels
print 8 idler wheels 4 for each track and 84 track pads to assemble you will need to buy some bolts to hold it together.

description.header: 6  1 1/2" long bolts with lock nuts they cost me $0.09 each.
description.text:
print all the parts and Body A will lock into Body B after you put in all the wheels. just be sure to have the Drive wheels facing the right direction and have the idle wheels in before you glue the tabs and press the two bodys together.
next just put the bolts for the idle wheels in and dont get them too tight they are axels and the wheels need to spin. finaly you need to assemble the track itself.
thats easy. get a soldering iron hot and start by melting a peice of fillament so the end is flatened out like a nail. cut it to the length of the bolts you bought. then stick the fillament into the 4 holes of the track pads and melt the other end of the fillament.
Repeat untill you have enough to wrap around the whole thing then do the last one when it is wrapped around the track body.

comments.text:
Ya, Tory, I printed out a couple sets of the tracks for a friend of mine who uses it on a 1/10 scale car. I don't have it here so can't get any pictures right now, and I don't know how to upload pictures here. I printed the track pieces 4 at a time, that took 1/2 hour per print. Printed PLA at .3/ layer X 50mm speed.
Was a fun project, that works GREAT. My friend loves it.
Thanks again,

remixed_from.author: frank1927
remixed_from.title: OXO QCTP Quick Change Tool Post Holder Mount

description.text:
I like the idea of holding the QCTP tools on the lathe itself, but I wanted something to make better use of space and to fit my 0xA tool holders. With this design you can seat the tool holders on both sides of the lathe back plate. That means you can fit 8-10 QCTP toolholders on a 7x10 mini lathe.

Note: the dovetail is 3% smaller than the nominal measurement of 0xA such that you can just drop the tools in and the support doesn't come off with a tool because of a too tight fit. If you want something to hold QCTP tools tightly, see my other design "anything on a lathe".

title: QIDI Tech I scalable spacer 10mm Axis
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: slip-in scalable spacer for glass, print platform etc. There are more of these floating around, however the ones I found were for the old z-axis or had indents for the screws and if you scaled them down the screw heads could hit. This can be scaled in your slicer to your height preference. The uploaded model is 3.3 mm which I use for the print-in-z plate, it does require slightly lowering (tightening) the build plate which was intentional.

Designed for http://blog.tinkercad.com/2012/03/19/design-a-chess-set-win-a-makerbot/ I thought it would be interesting to make Ice cubes in the shape of chess pieces, use food dye (or Kool-Aid) for coloring the black pieces(you could then play a variant of timed chess, where a piece is gone once it has melted beyond recognition). Warning: not recommended for cardboard chess boards.
I also thought about Chocolate chess, though I suspect eating the pieces you take would be required.
You could use this with just about any liquid that solidifies, such as latex, but I'm not sure why you would. This part was made with Tinkercad. Edit the part online at: https://tinkercad.com/things/dhmJvNcxGQj

While I doubt this will be anywhere as awesome as Action #Chess (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19733) I will try anyway.
I hope this will work with any liquid that solidifies at a temperature or over time. Note: I have not printed this (no 3d printer), if you do print it, please let me know of any issues, problems, or suggestions for improvements. Note 2: You should probably flip it up-side-down before printing.
  • Print, clean, and seal the connection
  • Fill with desired material.
  • let material solidify.
  • remove from molds.
  • play.

This is a pencil cup using a model of my own face on 3 sides.
The face model was extracted from a cone-beam CT scan that was done on my head to aid in treatment planning for orthodontics (braces) in 2007. I extracted the soft tissue using DeVide, then exported as an STL file. The STL file was brought into Mesh Lab where extraneous stuff (internal anatomy- sinuses, etc.) was removed, leaving a 3D zero thickness surface, saved as an STL file again. That file was brought into Blender where the edges were cleaned up, some surface problems smoothed, and the back closed.
There will be more designs from the same CT scan- I can select bone, etc, so there's an infinite range of possibilities.

Update: the latest version of slic3r is much smarter about generating support material and only generates support for this build under the chin and nose. It's much easier to clean up after printing!
This mash-up was made in Sketchup- the face STL was imported, then turned into a component, then duplicated and rotated to fit around the triangular cup. The cup was also saved as a component. Each component, in its final position, was exported as an STL file, the all four STL files were loaded into Mesh Lab and the file flattened so all four components were on the same layer. The whole thing was then exported as an STL file and reopened in NetFabb for final repairs.
The stl file was sliced using slic3r with 0.25 mm first layer and 0.2mm layers after with rectilinear grid support material at 2.5mm spacing and 15% rectilinear infill. I printed using Coex3D magenta ABS with the first layer stuck to the bed at 105C and then dropping to 75C for the remainder of the print. I used 3 solid top and bottom layers and 2 layer walls. The print was made on MegaMax and took about 9 hours.
I have uploaded the original CT scan files for anyone who wants to try playing with them. Just DL and unrar the archive.

description.text: A friend of mine was writing a computer program and needed a physical, and more tangible aide to visualize gear movements. He requested this be printed as soon as my printer arrived in May of 2016. I honored this request thinking such a simple mechanical device as a gear should not be so challenging. I was wrong to an extent. The failure was a simple one; I foolishly lowered the temperature of the hotend to the point where the extrusion stopped altogether. Not to be phased and running out of time in the early hours of the morning, I "pulled the plug". I removed the gears as they were and they looked pretty cool with the exposed honeycomb infill. I mounted them to a blank 1/2" plywood box that i had laying around with finishing nails. Placing them in such a random way proves to have an interesting effect when one expects the lines to line up at some point in the future. The effect is that they appear to be in chaos; randomly turning without returning to the original spot. Interestingly enough the chaos theory [( https://www.wolframscience.com/reference/notes/971c ) see the link for some notes on the chaos theory] is a heavily debated and ultimately unfinished mathematical equation which attempts to drill down to the most finite deterministic factors in a system to derive the result which one seeks. This is the true idea behind the more fun sounding "butterfly effect". As such I have found it useful in helping my son develop a conceptually sound understanding of this theories implications. Enjoy it for yourself, complete the print if you like or stop it mid way, perhaps a butterfly will flap in Indonesia as you print this and it will randomly fail forcing yours gears to have an exposed infill as well!?

Instead of using parts H & J outlined in D. Spaulding's, May 2016 edition of the D-Bot Build Guide, where it is a 40x20 mm piece of V-Slot joined perpendicularly with another 40x20 piece, I opted to go for a setup that uses a 40x20 joined to a 20x20. However, in order to use this, the "2-2x1_Plate" component can't be used. To get around this problem, I designed this component in SW to replace the original 2x1 plate that joins H & J to K.

Size changeable linear bearing done in freecad.

Inner and outer radius.

6 holes change the radius accordingly.

Don't have a clue on how todo full parameterisation, but as I get better of course quality of Freecad file will get better.

Found that in PLA their is usually about 0.2mm shrinkage in overall diameter. So this needs to be accounted for.

Found that once shrinkage is accounted for, a typical freeplay of about 0.05mm in the radius is possible. Some teasing of the part to get it onto the slide is necessary (first layer and first couple of layers are slightly more squashed - just bash it onto your slide material) Once on a little friction moving it along will sand the part to a neat accuracy (hot water from a kettle can help here too))

Have fun saving time bothering to go to linear bearing stores where most place's customer service is atrocious () Just use standard hollow aluminium tubes or steal ones.

description.text:
Version 2 is now out! It includes better grips, lids and other small improvements.

This is a fully CUSTOMIZABLE spinner fidget toy. It can use many things as weights from Ball Bearings and Quarters to Hex Nuts and Clay or even Magnets and concrete. You can use pretty much any center bearing you like by entering its dimensions. I have used the very common 608 as well as the smaller 625 bearings. I uploaded a few pictures to give you ideas. One of my favorite spinners uses plain old steel BB's! Make sure you select "Ball Bearing Retainer" for the Hole Type when using round objects. I strongly advise printing a Test Node(Choose Node Size Test from the Part dropdown.) to check the fit of the objects you choose. Most of the spinners I have printed are just loose enough to allow the ball bearings to rotate freely yet none of them have ever fallen out. I typically oversize the outer holes by .2mm.

I am perfecting the design and your feedback is appreciated!

TIPS:

  • If you choose the "Well" Outer Hole Type you will need to also print the "Well Lids" from the Part menu. They have a small lip that locks into the Well rim to close the chamber.
  • Accent Inserts can also be printed using another color to make cool patterned spinners.
  • They make really cool Tops if you use a Node_Radius of at least 28 and 5 or more 8mm-14mm Ball Bearing for weights. Just put a longer 3mm or similar screw through the Finger Grips. I filed the tip to a point and was able to get a top to spin well over 4 minutes with a short blast of compressed air!

i have ordered the ball bearings from both Amazon and Ebay. They are commonly sold as Slingshot Ammo. You can use any round objects as long as they have consistent diameters. Marbles will work, but can vary in size a bit.

Amazon Center Bearings
Amazon Slingshot Ammo
Ebay Ball Bearings

I am a Middle School Teacher and have informed my class that all donations made on behalf of this project will go to my classroom. Thanks and enjoy!

Notes:

Notes:

I print with 3 bottom layers, 3 top layers and 2 perimeters. I use higher infills (50-60%) on the finger grips. If using a screw in the finger grips, do a few test prints to get the screw-hole size adjusted to avoid drilling and tapping. I use a 3mm screw on all size grips. This is a very easy print and the recommended settings can be varied widely. Don't forget to change to "3D Print Quality" in the Display Mode dropdown when downloading the STL.

Use the "Node Size Test" part type to print a test node to make sure your ball bearing will snap into the bearing retainer. I like to use a vise or wood clamp to squeeze the bearings in. They will usually snap into place and be able to spin freely in their socket. If they are too tight just up the Outer_Hole_Size.

Print the Accent Inserts in a separate color for awesome designs!

Common Bearing Sizes:

625 - 16mm Outer_Diameter, 5mm Inner Bore, 5mm High
608 - 22mm Outer_Diameter, 8mm Inner Bore, 7mm High
624 - 13mm Outer_Diameter, 4mm Inner Bore, 5mm High
623 - 10mm Outer_Diameter, 3mm Inner Bore, 4mm High
605 - 14mm Outer_Diameter, 5mm Inner Bore, 5mm High
688 - 16mm Outer_Diameter, 8mm Inner Bore, 5mm High
606 - 17mm Outer_Diameter, 6mm Inner Bore, 6mm High

Outer Ball Bearing Hole Sizes:

Add .2mm-.3mm to these numbers for loose fit 
3/4"   Ball          19.05mm
5/8"   Ball          15.875mm
1/2"   Ball          12.7mm
7/16"  Ball          11.1mm
3/8"   Ball          9.53mm
1/4"   Ball          6.35mm

The ball bearing retainers work flawlessly on all sizes of ball bearings. The retaining ledge is very small and calculated automatically for any bearing. You might need a vise or clamp to get the ball bearings to "snap" into place if sized correctly. They should then be freely rotatable. You can order bags of 10 to 100 from Amazon or Ebay. Search for slingshot ammo.

remixed_from.author: c_wolsey
remixed_from.title: Anet A8 Electronics Case (Octopi, Relay + Mainboard)

title: Anet A8 Electronics Case Mosfet Remix (Octopi, Mosfet + Mainboard)

description.text:
I love the original design by c_wolsey but I wanted to have a mosfet instead of the relay so I decided to attempt modifying the design to suite.

Its a bit of a tight fit but it seems to all fit in well enough in the original case dimensions.
There is another case someone made in a similar design to this with a mosfet mount but the case is larger and doesn't seem like it will fit on the frame as nice as this design.

Things that I modified are:

  • Raised the Pi closer to the cover to make room for the mosfet under it.

  • Reinforced and increased the radius of the standoffs because I read people were having problems with the strength of the original standoffs.

  • Also redid all of the standoffs and screw holes.

  • Changed the top a little bit- moved the hole for the wiring to the other side.

  • Added a small hole in the bottom to run wires in.

  • Got rid of the slot for the ribbon cable. I don't plan to use one anytime soon, but when I do I can just snip one little piece of the vent holes out.

There are a couple little issues I've noticed after printing that I'll probably address in the design if anyone is interested in printing this.

  • I think the holes in the standoffs for screws are a bit small (2mm diameter) but I wanted to make sure there was enough strength there. I plan on just drilling them out a bit or finding screws that are a bit smaller for mine.

  • The mosfet edge supports are a bit tight, I had to trim a little off after printing to get it to fit down in there.

  • The support for the Pi on the corner directly under the ethernet port was in the way of one of the contacts for the port. Just trimmed a bit off the support with a knife and it clears fine now. The contact wasn't there on the 3D model of the Pi I used to modify this case.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

This is the first thing I've posted on here, and I have basically no experience working with 3D programs like sketchup, in fact this was my first attempt working with the program.
But I thought I'd share it because it might help someone else out.

comments.text: I made this for my A6. Only needed slight modifications. I just drilled 4 new holes just below the board mounts (just low enough to fit a M3 nut, bottom right is really tight), and used the original M3 screws and nuts to mount the enclosure to the machine. Only minor problems I ran into were that I had to remove the left support for the bottom of the RasPi (mine is a RPi 3 and the peg interfered with the protrusion under the board from the ethernet jack, and then further interfered with my cable to relocate my SD card slot). Used M2 screws to mount all components, anet board required washers since the holes in it are the same diameter as the head of a m2 screw. Also needed a place to mount my 12v to 5v regulator to power the RPi, but the mesh design of this enclosure made that easy to just ziptie to the side.

print_settings.Notes:: Designed to be the same thickness as the original perspex bracket so the hardware can be reused. I reoriented the extruder so that the bowden cable is on the same side as the stepper motor cable.

title: Lower rail extruder motor mount for Kossel 2020

description.text:
The standard Folger Kossel stepper mount is fine, and I have used it successfully for over a year, but I wanted a cleaner solution that would combine the bowden tube and cable braid, and provide better access to the extruder by mounting it one the lower rail. By combining the cable braid and bowden tube, there is less sag and catching of the cabling.

This bracket mounts the extruder with unimpeded access from the top, attached with two screws and drop-in t nuts to the top rail, and has a relief recess to rest the lower portion on the bottom 2020 rail.

A bracket to zip tie and secure the cable bundle from the arduino to the hotend is on the left hand side.

Printer:

Kossel mini 2020
